contentrichtext.text: '''Father John MacEnery''' (27 November 1797–18 February 1841) was a [[Roman Catholic]] priest from [[Limerick]], [[Ireland]] <ref>Erik Trinkaus and Pat Shipman, [http://books.google.com/books?id=PCqAAAAAMAAJ The Neandertals: changing the image of mankind], ISBN 0-394-58900-9, 1993</ref><ref>Edward Battersby Bailey, [http://books.google.com/books?id=Od8_AAAAIAAJ Charles Lyell], 1963</ref> and early [[archaeologist]]<ref>Stringer, C., ''Homo Britannicus: The Incredible Story of Human Life in Britain'', Penguin, London, 2006, ISBN 978-0-14-101813-3</ref> who came to Devon as Chaplain to the Cary family at Torre Abbey in 1822.<ref>Malcolm Todd and Andrew Fleming, [http://books.google.com/books?id=b_ogAAAAMAAJ The South West to AD 1000], ISBN 0-582-49273-4, 1987</ref> In 1825, 1826 and 1829,<ref>A. Bowdoin Van Riper, [http://books.google.com/books?id=zuBGhCrxHUcC Men among the mammoths: Victorian science and the discovery of human prehistory], ISBN 0-226-84991-0, 1993</ref> he investigated the prehistoric remains at [[Kent's Cavern]] in [[Devon]],<ref>E. M. M Alexander, Father John MacEnery: scientist or charlatan?, Devonshire Association Report and Transactions, ed. H.H. Wilker, 96, 113-46, ISSN 03097994, 1964</ref> having been shown the cave by [[Thomas Northmore]].<ref>Rosemary Hill, ''God's Architect: Pugin and the Building of Romantic Britain'', ISBN 0-300-15161-6, 2009</ref> MacEnery concluded that the [[palaeolithic]] flint tools he found in the same [[archaeological context|context]]s as the bones of extinct prehistoric mammals meant that early humans and the creatures such as [[mammoth]]s co-existed.<ref>[http://books.google.com/books?id=vC4c3Kx746QC&pg=PA62&dq=john+macenery&hl=en&ei=XZycTYmWAobs4wbJt5jiBg&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=8&ved=0CEoQ6AEwBw#v=onepage&q=john%20macenery&f=false ''The Dragon Seekers: How an Extraordinary Circle of Fossilists Discovered the Dinosaurs and Paved the Way for Darwin'', Christopher McGowan, 2002, p 62]</ref> His contemporaries had great difficulty reconciling his findings to their pre-[[Charles Darwin|Darwin]]ian, creationist view of the [[History of Earth|earth's history]]. MacEnery left Torquay and his cave research in 1830. He never published and it was left to [[William Pengelly]] to publicise and explore his findings in 1859, years after MacEnery's death at age 43. ==References== {{reflist}} =External links= *[http://kentscavern.co.uk/macenery.html Portrait of John MacEnery] *[http://www.frithphotos.com/torquay/photos/john-macenerys-grave-2005_T62715/ John MacEnery's grave] {{Persondata <!-- Metadata: see [[Wikipedia:Persondata]]. --> | NAME = Macenery, John | ALTERNATIVE NAMES = | SHORT DESCRIPTION = | DATE OF BIRTH = 1796 | PLACE OF BIRTH = | DATE OF DEATH = 1841 | PLACE OF DEATH = }} {{DEFAULTSORT:Macenery, John}} [[Category:1796 births]] [[Category:1841 deaths]] [[Category:English archaeologists]] [[Category:English Roman Catholic priests]] [[Category:19th-century Roman Catholic priests]] {{UK-Christian-clergy-stub}} {{RC-clergy-stub}} {{UK-archaeologist-stub}}
